book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
user_name: Sandy *The world could end while I was reading and I would never notice*
text: EXCERPT: And into this (pub) one day wandered a guy called Gordon, with his vertical-stripe velvet coat, his shoes that turned up at the front, his Brylcreemed hair, his Ascot tie and his violin. And a wierd look about his face. I became instantly friendly with him. Gordon only had one eye - he'd lost the other one in a motoring accident in Spain - but that's not when we discovered it, that came later. We found that out one day when it was somebody's birthday in the pub. 'Happy birthday!' - chink-chink - 'Happy birthday! All the best!' - chink-chink - 'Yeah, happy birthday to you!' - chink-chink. And Gordon went; 'Yeah, happy birthday!' and he lifted his glass and chink-chinked it with his glass eye. We were amazed: 'Did you see that? He chinked the glass off his fucking eye!'He was a crazy bloke. He drank Guinness and when he needed to pee, he'd take his eye out and put it in the foam, because there were a lot of thieves in the pub. We called them 'mine-sweepers', because they'd go up and grab somebody else's glass, saying, 'That's mine!' Well, they'd try it with Gordon's - 'That's mine!' - and then they'd see this eye floating in the foam: 'Aaaggghhh!'Well I was walking through the pub one day, and he came in the door with his arm in a sling. I said, 'What happened to you?' He said, 'You'll never believe it. I was driving up Sauchiehill Street, I was scratching my good eye, and I ran into a bus.' He'd thought because his artificial eye was so expensive he could see through it!ABOUT 'TALL TALES AND WEE STORIES': In December 2018, after fifty years of belly-laughs, energy and outrage, Billy Connolly announced his retirement from live stand-up comedy. It had been an extraordinary career.When he first started out in the late sixties, Billy played the banjo in the folk clubs of Scotland. Between songs, he would improvise a bit, telling anecdotes from the Clyde shipyard where he'd worked. In the process, he made all kinds of discoveries about what audiences found funny, from his own brilliant mimes to the power of speaking irreverently about politics or explicitly about sex. He began to understand the craft of great storytelling. Soon the songs became shorter and the monologues longer, and Billy quickly became recognised as one of the most exciting comedians of his generation.Billy's routines always felt spontaneous. He never wrote scripts, always creating his comedy freshly on stage in the presence of a live audience. A brilliant comic story might be subsequently discarded, adapted or embellished. A quick observation or short anecdote one night, could become a twenty-minute segment by the next night of a tour.Billy always brought a beautiful sense of the absurd to his shows as he riffed on his family, hecklers, swimming in the North Sea or naked bungee jumping. But his comedy can be laced with anger too. He hates pretentiousness and calls out hypocrisy wherever he sees it. His insights about the human condition have shocked many people, while his unique talent and startling appearance on stage gave him license to say anything he damn well pleased about sex, politics or religion.Billy got away with it because he has always had the popular touch. His comedy spans generations and different social tribes in a way that few others have ever managed.MY THOUGHTS: I bought this book from a small independent bookstore in Russell, northern New Zealand, when we were up there on holiday over the 2019/20 Christmas/New Year period. I love Billy Connolly and was lucky enough to see him live last time he toured New Zealand. I came out of his show with my mascara all down my face, and my sides ached for days. Billy writes exactly as he talks, so I could hear him as I was reading. Some of the stories were familiar to me, some were new. All were entertaining. No one escapes his attention. Not his wife, daughters, friends, workmates, or the scone loving, brogue, twinset and heather coloured tweed wearing elderly ladies of Scotland. If you're a Billy Connolly fan, or simply need a good laugh, this is the book you need. It has joined The World of Pooh: The Complete Winnie-The-Pooh and the House at Pooh Corner by A.A. Milne as my all time favourites. They are never put away on a shelf, but instead are always somewhere close at hand where I can pick one up and while away a few minutes, or hours. ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐THE AUTHOR: William "Billy" Connolly, Jr., CBE is a Scottish comedian, musician, presenter and actor. He is sometimes known, especially in his native Scotland, by the nickname The Big Yin (The Big One). His first trade, in the early 1960s, was as a welder (specifically a boilermaker) in the Glasgow shipyards, but he gave it up towards the end of the decade to pursue a career as a folk singer in the Humblebums and subsequently as a soloist. In the early 1970s he made the transition from folk-singer with a comedic persona to fully-fledged comedian, a role in which he continues. He also became an actor.It is as a stand-up comedian that Connolly is best known. His observational comedy is idiosyncratic and often off-the-cuff. He has outraged certain sectors of audiences, critics and the media with his free use of the word "fuck". He has made jokes relating to masturbation, blasphemy, defecation, flatulence, haemorrhoids, sex, his father's illness, his aunts' cruelty and, in the latter stages of his career, old age (specifically his experiences of growing old). In 2007 and again in 2010, he was voted the greatest stand-up comic on Channel 4's 100 Greatest Stand-Ups.Connolly has been married to comedian and psychologist Pamela Stephenson since 1989. In the book Billy, and in a December 2008 online interview, Connolly states he was sexually abused by his father between the ages of 10 and 15. He believes this was a result of the Catholic Church not allowing his father to divorce after his mother left the family. Due to this, Connolly has a "deep distrust and dislike of the Catholic church and any other organization that brainwashes people". In a 1999 interview with "The Sunday Herald" Connolly condemned the SNP as "racist" and the new Scottish parliament as a "joke".In November 1998, Connolly was the subject of a two-hour retrospective entitled Billy Connolly: Erect for 30 Years, which included tributes from Judi Dench, Sean Connery, Whoopi Goldberg, Robin Williams, Dustin Hoffman, and Eddie Izzard. DISCLOSURE: I own my copy of Tall Tales and Wee Stories written by Billy Connolly and published by Two Roads. All opinions expressed in this review are entirely my own personal opinions. For an explanation of my rating system please refer to my Goodreads.com profile page or the about page on sandysbookaday.wordpress.com This review and others are also published on Twitter, Instagram and my webpage https://sandysbookaday.wordpress.com/...

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Rude, lead and crude, with quite a bit of profanity thrown in, but entertaining nonetheless. I've never watched his stand up routines, but became aquatinted with this comedian by watching PBS. If you've watched his stand up you may already have heard some of the tales in this book. From his growing up in a tenament in Glasgow to his Catholic schooling, there are incidents that left me laughing. I sent to Catholic school, and could identify even if we were schooled county's apart.His travels and opinions of other countries, I particularly liked his explanation on why the Swiss yodeled. Too funny! Some of course fell flat, the nature of the heart where comedy is concerned, but there is plenty within for one to find comedic gems. Like I said though, he does not mince nor minimize his words, opinions, profanity at all. A much welcomed comedic break.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I'm a big fan of Billy Connolly, as a comedian, a storyteller and just generally as an all round interesting good bloke who is great to listen to. But this book did not do a lot for me, except make me reflect what a great performer he is. The book made me think of scientific reductionism - that tendency of some scientists to break a problem into tiny parts and see the solution in terms of those tiny parts instead of retaining some holistic vision. For Billy Connolly is more than the sum of his parts. If you read these stories without any idea who Billy Connolly was, I suspect you would find them neither terribly interesting nor amusing. In fact, I was surprised how comically thin many of these tall tales and wee stories were. And yet some of them I think I can actually remember him telling and laughing at.I think this comes down to the fact that he is overall a brilliant performer. And to understand this brilliance you need to hear his voice, see his face, sense his energy levels when he was performing, - and so on. The words written down on paper just don't do it for me on their own - but if you add him back into them, they will. There were a few bits which were either slightly amusing or interesting, but slim pickings from a 320 or so pages long book. My advice, give this a miss. He has written other stuff - I'd say go for that.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Over the years I've seen Billy Connolly's numerous stand up routines on TV, but I've always regretted not seeing him live on stage. To make up for this in a small way I treated myself to a signed copy of this brilliantly entertaining book.Connolly has put together his best "tall tales & wee stories" from a lifetime of stand up comedy. There are a few stories here that are new to me, but even the routines I know well still made me laugh out loud. The stories all flow beautifully & so many of them are classics it's impossible to choose any favourites. A great collection of tales from a real legend.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: One of the reasons I love Billy Connelly’s stories is that he tells them just like I do myself - only funny. Unnecessary background, side tracks, lost threads, missed points, picked up threads, another side story, completely unrelated facts about characters in the story, oh and look - there’s the punchline! I was wondering a little if there could be something in what some reviewers said that these would work less well in written form, but that went out the window at the end of the second sentence and by the end of the second paragraph I was huffing snd puffing and laughing out loud. Can honestly not remember when a book made me do that last time. The missing star is mainly because I felt the book lost pace towards the end and the last few chapters would actually have been better to leave out. Billy (as I expected) also veers a tad close to slapstick and/or toilet humour at times. It’s a great read though and very strong four stars.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I have been a fan of Billy Connolly for as long as I can remember and sadly never took the opportunity to go and see him live before he retired in 2018. I have seen many of his recorded performances though and I think all of his travelogues as he has been around various parts of the world.This book is a collection of some of his best-known stories that he tells as part of his sets. He is a very human comedian, he is as happy to rip the piss out of himself as he is to call out the hypocrisy of others whilst giving you a stitch laughing about it so much.Some of the tall tales and wee stories in here I have heard before. That doesn’t make them any less funny though. One of my favourites was his description of swimming in the North Sea as a Child! Provided you don’t mind a bit (ok a lot) of profanity then there is almost certainly something in here that will make you laugh. Great stuff and thanks for all the laughs, Billy.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I love Billy Connolly having seen him live two or three times and watched all his television programmes including the excellent 'World Tour' series in England, Scotland, Australia and New Zealand. I also have a few of the live DVDs.So I was looking forward to this book. It is a let down. If, like me, you have seen all the above then you will know the majority of the tall tales and wee stories he tells here. There are some I have not heard before though but that does not really make up for it. It is a dip in-and-out book for sure.He says that when you read the book you will hear him and that is so true. Who is this book aimed at? I am not really sure. For Connolly fans it is going over old ground. For someone that does not know him I would say get the 'World Tour' DVDs.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy ConnollyBilly Connolly, is one of those comedians who everybody knows and loves, his innate honesty and sharp wit, have had audiences in stitches for five decades. I read this on the bus on the way to and from work and was giggling all the way there and back. The drivers must have thought I'd lost by mind. Highlights include a trip to Births Deaths and Marriages and a chapter on why multiple orgasms have put tremendous pressure on men and women have no idea. This book is typical Billy and I loved every word of it.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Good fun running through transcripts of a lot of the better routines (and some that don't translate very well, falling flat on the page, the absence of the performer of a text never so keenly felt). The ultimate realisation is that Connolly was an even better stage presence than imagined to have elevated some of this way beyond its merit. Ultimately, great spending time with that voice again.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: What makes the inhabitants of Glasgow so eternally fascinating! Here, Billy Connolly gives insight through his tenement childhood through his life, told in short vignettes, some laugh-out-loud hilarious. In fact, his secret to enjoying life without fail is to be sure not to lose your ability to laugh. At times curmudgeonly, at times kind, often very raw and profane, but always honest, and with that wee twinkle. Full disclosure - I never had the pleasure of seeing Sir Connolly's standup in person. In fact, I first became aware of him through his portrayal in the film Mrs. Brown, and didn't realize acting was only one of his skills, and not the one he was best known for.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Ach, sorry Billy. This book just isn't that funny. Perhaps my expectations were too high.Connelly starts this book by conceding that he is no longer well enough to stand in front of an audience for over two hours. He is very open about living with Parkinson's Disease but he is also now 78 years old.He was always a very physical comedian; his act was slapstick in many ways with a lot of the humour arising from his gestures and facial expressions. It doesn't translate on to the page especially well. It is indeed a book of 'wee stories' - an there's a gey lot o' them. This is something to dip into from time to time for a wee smile rather than to read in one go.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: CYNICAL, HALF-HEARTED RECYCLED CASH IN!Imagine one of your favourite bands or singers who had been recording music for around half a century, decided to put those songs in book form without any hint of the music at all. You would rightly be confused by the move. Beyond the cash generating aspect, what would be the point?...Well that is basically what Connolly has done here.The main problem with this book is that almost all of it has appeared in at least one, sometimes two previous books and a lot of his stand up. It really feels a bit cheeky and lazy when we are getting the exact same stories dragged out for two books in a row?...Surely the readership deserves some quality control?...instead of recycling the same old stories again and again.Of course this has its funny moments now and then, but the truth is that too many of these stories do not translate well onto the page at all. I’ve heard many of them on his stand up stuff and it is delivered a lot better, so much of it is lost when committed to the page, all the drama, nuance and volume stripped away it can feel incredibly dull and disappointing. On the positive side, this is a quick read and it’s an easy read, but overall there is a good reason why Connolly has not published too many books in his half century involved in the creative and performing arts. Some of these are really awful and not only fall flat but fail miserably and really don’t do the great man justice at all.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: All my favourite stories in written form. Billy Connolly has such a special place in my heart and I always get really emotional talking about him but this one made me laugh rather than cry. I had tears running down my face reading my favourite skits I was laughing that much. It took me five minutes to read one bloody paragraph about the knitted balaclava because I was hysterically laughing. They are just as funny in written form as they are on stage. Love you big yin!

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I saw Billy on stage a few years ago and I laughed until it hurt. I think seeing him live definitely helped while reading the book, as I could imagine him strutting round the stage telling his tall tales and wee stories. He's written the book exactly the way he talks, swear words and all.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I t had me laughing out loud! Thank you Billy.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I’ve been a massive Billy Connolly fan for many years. I’ve got lots of DVDs featuring his standup and travelogues, and I was lucky enough to see him live twice. He never fails to make me laugh, even just on a chat show. So it was with great sadness I heard about his retirement, although entirely understandable in his circumstances.I was looking forward to reading this book in which he has gathered many of his most famous stories for posterity. Billy never really told ‘jokes,’ they were always funny anecdotes and tales, often poking fun at himself or other absurdities he saw in every day life. He often talked about sex and bodily functions, and was very sweary and he makes no apology for that, so the book would not be for anyone who did not like this in his live shows because Billy is exactly the same in the book as when performing. If you did love his humour though, you will find many of your favourite stories within these pages.The book is split in to chapters on different, loosely connected topics, but otherwise it is fairly randomly organised with just little anecdotes and longer ones interspersed with comments, thoughts and musings on his life and career. Some people won’t like it because it isn’t a particular linear format, but then Billy’s comedy was never like that. He would start on a topic and then wander off at a tangent when other things occurred to him before looping back round to the original story (or sometimes not!), so the book is a good reflection of his style and really brought him to life for me.I could hear his voice telling these familiar, and some unfamiliar, stories very clearly. Parts of it made me laugh out loud and I had to keep stopping to read bits aloud to The Irishman who kept asking me what I was laughing at. It was a book that really cheered me up during this lockdown. However, it is not the same as watching Billy perform, and you realise how much his expressions and gestures and movements added to the comedy of his story-telling. The ‘Wildebeest’ example illustrates this best. It is many people’s favourite story of Billy’s, but it just isn’t as funny when you can’t see him doing the vacant expression of the wildebeest and the actions of the lions as they plan their attack.Overall, I really enjoyed reading this but it can’t replace Billy’s performances, and I for one will miss him terribly. I wish I could have met him in real life just once before Parkinson’s started to take effect. I’m sure it would have been great craic.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: The whole opening of the book leads you to believe that these are the stories that Billy really wanted to share and how important writing this book was.Its actually just a transcript of a bunch the Billy's comedy, which i feel takes away a lot of the fun of these humorous tales when you have to read misspelled words instead of hearing Billy's strong Scottish accent, or reading the gestures he did instead of seeing them. And not being surrounded by a laughing audience means that when one of these tales doesn't elicit a chuckle, you just sit there in the awkward silence this book invoked into the atmosphere and question where it's worth trying for another. A few chuckles did arise, but they were few and far between, to the point where i decided to just cut my losses and accept that as a young straight sober not Scottish guy, I'm probably not the target audience for this comedy or this book.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Ah Billy Connolly is just such an icon. His comedy is timeless and classic. I have loved watching his stand up over the years on TV and once had tickets to see him live - which I so regret not being able to use. This book is a collection of small stories from his life, some we've heard before, some new. I found myself reading it in my head using his voice and I think this made it so much funnier. Please read this if you are a fan. Even if you aren't, you will probably enjoy it nonetheless.https://thebeautifulbookbreak.com

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Now that Billy has retired from stand up comedy, he’s finally been persuaded to write down some of his more well known stories. I was reading this and I had his voice in my head, and I was having to stifle laughter when reading this not to wake anyone up. Very funny stories and a great read.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Found myself peeing myself laughing at this one. I love Billy Connolly and this was just the ticket for a lockdown read to dip in and out of. I could visualise him delivering the lines and could hear his voice. I defy you not to grin like an idiot when reading this. LOVED IT!

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: So, if you're likely to be offended by the swearing, you may as well fuck off now.This is pure Billy. But it's one-dimensional.If watching Billy is like eating a delicious 3-course meal, then reading this book is like looking at the menu.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: “…and laugh. Always look to laugh. Nothing else will ever keep you going like laughter.”No surprise but I laughed out loud the whole way through.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I love Billy Connolly! Always have, always will. First came to know of him whilst growing up outside Glasgow and my mum not allowing me to watch him on TV or listen to him on radio. And of course, being forbidden made me secretly seek him out. My first time seeing him on stage was in Bournemouth in the early 80s and some of the audience walking out!! He actually addressed me a couple of times cos he told some jokes that Glaswegians (or near enough) would REALLY get, so I was in hysterics and pretty obvious.Last time was in 2016 on his High Horse tour where the effects of Parkinson's was obvious, mostly because he pointed them out and made jokes about them! So having this book is great if you're a fan of the man and his legendary comedy. I've also watched him on TV interviews, his Audience With shows, listened to radio interviews, watched his movies (he's also a terrific actor) so many of the stories/anecdotes, I've heard before. Some remembered more than others and some I'd forgotten, but the way he writes them, you can visualise him performing it and hear his voice saying it, and they were just as funny as the first time I'd heard them .... and some even moreso. He really is a fabulous raconteur and, as he says himself, he's not really a joke teller as such, just shares his brilliant observations of and opinions on life, love, sex, rules, "beige", acting, his childhood and much, much more. It's been a while since any book made me laugh out loud (even whilst in bed reading at stupid o'clock in the morning when I didn't want to put it down)!A really easy, hilarious read. I'd give it a 4.5 out of 5.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I grew up listening to Billy, I remember hearing the jobby weecher and the Crucifixion on records my elder brother would play while I was still in short trousers. He's been a part of my life for that long, and now he's retiring from the stage. But it's not all bad news, for he leaves us this, a collection of all his best stories, but written down. Given how much I've heard from him, anything I read, I hear in his voice, which when you include the sex noises is a little weird. He's the finest comedian Scotland has ever produced, this shows why.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I have had this book on the “to read” list for awhile now but it was the announcement that Billy Connolly will be streaming his “farewell” soon on TV which made me pick it up and I am ever so glad I did. A hilarious collection of Connolly’s stand up performances which are able to be enjoyed in written form without loosing any of their power.As a fan I was able to easily imagine him telling these stories as only he can, prancing and jumping around and found myself laughing out loud on more than a few occasions.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Bloody Brilliant. I was so lucky to have seen Billy perform live. It’s so sad that he’s given up live shows but this book captures some of my favourite stories and it’s a book I know I will read again and again and continue to laugh out loud!!!!

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Always liked Billy Connolly but his humour, for me, is better live. The book covers a lot of stories that people, who like Billy Connolly, will already be familiar with.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: There is no plot to this book, but that’s okay. Connolly is one of the funniest people I know of, and his style of funny is not jokes or terse anecdotes; he starts talking about one subject, veers off in a Grandpa Simpson way (except the detour actually has a point), goes back to the main thread, veers again, finally gets to the end, in the process saying “f***” about 500 times and bringing sex into the story at least once. By the time I get to the end of the story, I’m lying on my side, tears running down, gasping and wheezing and trying not to wake my husband, because I stayed up a good deal of the night reading, unable to quit. So, yeah, I liked the book. I wish I could have seen Connolly perform live, but at least I’ve seen him on TV enough that, as I read the book, I heard it being told in his voice.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: When I did my PhD in West Yorkshire, I discovered Billy Connolly and I bought some tapes of shows of his, which made loads of trips very enjoyable indeed. And so, my husband surprised me with this book last week, and I just needed to read it immediately! Because of the tapes I even imagined the text as read by BC himself ;-) A lot of the stories I already knew, but most of them are just brilliant and I keep on laughing, even if I hear/read them for the 50th time. But there´s also some lesson to be learned, and I quote "Acting your age is about as sensible as acting your street number. You can volunteer to take life seriously, but it´s going to get you anyway. it´s going to win against you in the end. It´s harsh, and you an either break down and complain about how miserable your life is, or you can have a go at it and survive. ... And laugh. Always look to laugh. Nothing else will ever keep you going like laughter." AMEN

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: A half autobiography, a half story book!This is a book full of what I can only presume is Billy’s content when he used to be up on stage making people laugh out loud, which the book makes you do as well.You get glimpses of his life through stories and funny moments made all the more real by the Scottish words heavily sprinkled throughout. All in all and I credibly enjoyable story book - lots of swearing though so perhaps if that’s not what you enjoy it may not be as enjoyable for you. As a Scottish gal myself it doesn’t bother me in the slightest.The only thing I really didn’t like was that anytime he was talking about a noise, he spelt it out in full: eg ahhhhhhhhhhhhhh and honestly I HATE this 😂 I never hear a noise just see lots of letters, but that’s personal to me so probably won’t be an issue for anyone else!

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Every time I didn't think this worked at all I was suddenly cracking up at a familiar routine and hearing his voice - of course. The Big Yin. A gem. So many gems here. But still, it's not like seeing him live, nor reading his thoughts not meant for a stage, nor even watching a DVD or stream of his best live content. But it's a nice thing to have and hold dear as his life moves on its later stages. He's a legend and there's some great stuff here. That said, sometimes you cringe at the context-less or dated set-ups for rather flat punchlines too; the burden of 'reading' material that was shaggy-dog even if crafted, the burden of having an oral tradition tapped out on a computer for some sort of extra posterity.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I'm a great fan of Billy Connolly the comedian, a lot of the stories in this selection, he has told on stage. Now he has retired from stand up as he has Parkinson's Disease, he is also in his late seventies. What works on stage doesn't work as well on the printed page. Live you would be hard pressed to find a funnier comedian, but it is not just the material; it is his unique delivery, the reaction to the audience and his reaction to their reaction which makes it hilarious. We are social animals, at a comedy club, we often laugh because those around us are laughing but when reading alone we rarely laugh out loud. Billy Connolly has an absurd take on life, which is amusing but works so much better on stage.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I wasn't going to read this but I got it as a gift. The thing is if you're a huge Billy Connolly fan (and I am) then the book is a bit pointless. You've already internalised the contents. The book comprises of transcriptions of his act over the years. I've been watching his DVDs since I was 14, so I skipped over most of the pages due to already knowing what was written in them.Having said that, there was still some stuff that was new to me, I still laughed a good bit, and the final chapters are rather touching. I'm still glad that I read it and I definitely don't begrudge Billy for the book.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: It is a lovely book which I will treasure not just for all the stories, most of which I have heard several times but also about his whole approach to this book; he states that you can read it in his voice and I did, every word plus it's the twinkle he has in his eyes when he relates them, I could see that twinkle with every tale. I have loved Billy since the first time I saw him many years ago on a black and white telly - yes, that long ago on Michael Parkinson's show.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: A few good chuckles here and there. Started off good, middle was pretty bland and boring. But the end jokes were pretty damn good. I was going to rate it 2 stars but the last 100 pages were great. All of it was just just the same material from his live stand ups, so some of it wasn’t as good for me because I’ve already heard em a hundred times, but all in all, this book gave me a good chuckle. Wasn’t as good as I had hoped, but turned out to be okay in the end.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: This collection of anecdotes and set pieces from the decades of Billy Connolly's stand up musings should be read carefully on the understanding that there will come at least one wee story which sneaks up on you and causes the laughter to explode out of your nostrils at the least appropriate time.Best read on a bus or train while surrounded by unaware commuters.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: HilariousFunny from start to finish. Because l have seen a lot of his shows, I know about 70% of the stories in this book. It's the fourth book, either featuring Billy Connolly or written by him that I have read. Anyone who liked a good laugh and can see the world through his eyes will not be disappointed. If you are easily offended this may not be the book for you. Like many great comedians he gives it straight. People sometimes don't like that. Otherwise it's a great read.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Very much a retelling of his funniest monologues, in print format. Now there were observations that I hadn't seen/heard before which did make me laugh out loud but this is probably best for those not familiar with the big yin. Not for the easily offended which I am not. Particularly enjoyed the dwarf story which was a new one to me.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Just a short note... when reading this book, and I did read it in one day, you will hear Billy’s voice constantly (at least if you ever watched one of his live shows)I love his stories, I love his style! I love this book!

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: A pleasure to read and 'hear' his voice in all the stories, familiar and new. For an ex-Glaswegian (if you can ever be) it was partly a road trip in memories and partly just an interesting perspective as always from Billy.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Loved Billy’s Wee Stories at first, then got a little bored towards the end of the book. Not sure why? But I obviously finished the book. Don’t like to not complete a book. On the whole, glad I read it for Billy.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I have always loved Billy Connolly. However, I don’t think most of this material reads well. For it to be really funny requires his brilliant delivery and physical presence. It just (mostly) made me want to watch his old shows. Strong ending though.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Don’t read in public! I absolutely loved this book. I laughed my way through it. At times I had to put it down I was unable to continue reading for laughing! Definitely one to dip into if you need cheering up.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I love Billy, so this was great for me. A collection of short stories, just like he is on stage :)

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Great but you had to see him live

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Really enjoyed this with some laugh out loud tales

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: 4.5. A treasure, full of my favorite stand-up routines Billy Connolly has ever done.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Excellent read. It's mostly his stand up stuff but who cares? Brings back memories of seeing him live and all you have to do is imagine it's Billy himself reading it to you.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I absolutely loved this book. Just lots of wee stories and what’s more I read the whole thing in Billy’s accent. Great story teller and all round legend

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: It was alright. I mainly read it because of a negative review on Amazon. Someone was appalled by the language and, yes, there is swearing in it but nothing too over the top. The style did wear after a while.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: And now for something completely different for me to read! At the outset, Billy Connolly states that ‘he writes like he talks’ and he really does. This book is laugh-out-loud funny; deep aching belly laughs. His comedy translates well to the written format. Connolly is a master of mixing unrelated topics and infers great humour from mundane life activities. I did not realise that his performances are totally unscripted (he only takes a short list of topics on stage) and he leverages his ‘list’ to see what direction his stories can go in, generating variety within his story telling. He follows where his brain takes him; a kind of stream of consciousness or improvisation approach. Overall a great read and a deep insight into a great mind.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Can't go wrong with this one. Started it last night and was shaking with laughter (in bed) within a page - really. I think I was annoying the Wife with my shaking cos she's trying to read history, but I couldn't help it, every second sentence paints a funny image. Impossible to read with anything other than Billy's voice in your head, which just makes it more entertaining. This guy will be such a sad loss when he goes.Finished it now, and the strange thing is that if you force yourself NOT to hear Billy's voice as you're reading, then it isn't all that funny! It's his personality that makes these stories hilarious (or even poignant). The very last pages are the ones you'll remember the most: laugh as often as you can and don't worry about embarrassing yourself because "you're a long time looking at the lid". Aye!

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: A collection of Billy's finest anecdotes: beautifully compiled but sadly the magic of his delivery isn't there. My head says 3 stars and my heart says 5. Today my heart wins.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: A good read. More of a written collection of the stories from his comedy gigs over the years. They are entertaining but it emphasises the point that it takes a good comedian to deliver a story to make them even funnier.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: A great book indeed. I love that you can go to any page at all, & find a great story. I've never laughed like that at a book before.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Very funny. Laughing to the last pages!!

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Made me grin and giggle and at some points so funny my eyes would water and yes, get funny looks off people!

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Funny as ever. All The big yin's best stuff. I laughed at every page!

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I just loved this! I laughed so much whilst sitting in the waiting room for a hospital appointment that I had to put the book away as I was worried that they would wheel me off and keep me. You can really hear Billy talking to you just like during one of his shows and it leaves you with a big smile on your face. What's not to love!

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I don't like giving this book just one star as it's nicely produced and well edited, but it's actually a bit of a cheat.What I mean by this is that all it is a collection of Billy's stand-up routines, all of which are hilarious when he delivers them on stage but they fall flat on the page. There are a few great stories but most of them are anything but; the fact that I knew most of them wasn't the problem as I can listen to him on YouTube indefinitely (in fact, I would take an audio recordings of his comedy onto my desert island).If only the publisher's had had the courage to be honest it could have made for a much better book; they could have had a preface by the editor who transcribed the material with a related commentary; or, if Billy actually did this mundane task himself, surely he'd say something about it in the intro. I've transcribed audio material before and it's really hard work, as is the editing that has to then follow.There's no clue on the cover or front matter about who did the dirty work but in the acknowledgements the first name to get a thank you (and his own sentence) is Nick Davies. Who is Nick Davies? I will ask Google right now ... it turns out he's a bigshot editor who's worked for some of the main London publishing houses. I assume he's too high and mighty to have done this transcribing task himself (maybe Billy actually did it?. Maybe one of his household minions?) What I do know is that publishers will sell their own mother to get their hands on a book by a celebrity of Billy's stature, as it's like making a sequel of a popular film -- there's a ready-made audience ready to buy it however indifferent its quality may be.This is what Nick Davies said in The Bookseller's puff piece about the book:“As his many millions of fans will know, Billy’s stories can be rude, warm-hearted, anarchic, joyful, angry, far-fetched, down-to-earth and everything in between. They are also beautifully constructed, brilliantly paced and deeply funny. I’ve written to Billy at various points over the last 15 years to ask if he would bring these stories to the printed page and I’m thrilled that he has finally agreed. Tall Tales is an absolute treat of a book that will delight readers everywhere.”In conclusion, it's important to get Billy's jokes in book form -- particularly for people like me of a Scottish persuasion. But I would have appreciated a description of how the book came together and who was the poor sod who did the actual work.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: 3.5This was jolly good fun. It's got a lot of hilarious stories from Billy, classic bits from his stand-up, amazing folk tales and jokes. The thing is, Billy is a riot when telling these tales and they really come to life when he's enacting them, so by only reading them you don't get as much from them. Nevertheless, they're written in his style so you can almost hear him when reading. Great book for any Big Yin fan.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: There was many occasions while reading this book where the dog looked at me strangely as I was laughing out loud so much I occassionally snorted. If you love Billy Connelly you'll love this book, there are some stories you'll recognise (scratchy wool and balaclava) and lots of new ones. 🤣🤣🤣

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I laughed out loud (not the kindle edition but a real book).

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: More stars required - without doubt the funniest book I’ve ever read and I know already that I will re-read it. What an absolute legend. Laughed out loud throughout this book, laughing thinking back and I know I’ll continue to laugh. Mission accomplished Outstandingly good. Everyone should read this - in case you can’t tell I LOVED this book

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Brilliant !Funniest book I've read in ages. Although probably helps if you can "ken a wee bittae Scottish".

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: This was fun with many of Connolly's classics (Christmas Dinner, Dwarf on the Bus, etc.). I found it to be a slow read, though, as it was necessary to hear his voice in my head as I read. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone without any familiarity with his stand-up comedy, though. It also helped to read with a smart phone at the ready to look up all of the unfamiliar Scottish slang.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: A very light and amusing read featuring all his classic stories. Not quite the same as watching him tell them in the hilarious way that he does but still great fun.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I've always liked watching Billy Connolly's stand up. He doesn't tell jokes as such. His humour is primarily observational with the addition of his own style of speaking and the language of the Clyde shipyards. On stage over the years that worked. In my opinion this does not transfer to the written form. This book is just a collection of the stories he has told over the years interspersed with some rants about modern life. These rants made him sound like Jeremy Clarkson, a comparison which I am sure Connolly would hate. I got the feeling that much of the material was just transcripts from his shows, collated and then printed as a book. When I read them, one after the other, most of them were not funny.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: After retiring from doing live shows at the end of last year, Billy Connolly was persuaded to put pen to paper and write some of his stories down.It says something about how may times I have seen the Big Yin on stage that I was familiar with the majority of the stories in the book.Still didn't stop me laughing until I was breathless and crying.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I have never laughed so much as when I read this book. It’s inevitably read in Billy’s voice and his mad accent and take on life with sound affects to boot. Not so much a tale of his life but many hilarious anecdotes and wee stories. Some apparently true. This is one for the real fan. I bloody loved it!

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I read this book in a day, very nearly in one sitting. It’s been years (honestly about 15!) since I read “Billy” by his wife Pamela and I had reservations that this wouldn’t add much. Boy was I wrong. Having never been lucky enough to see Billy perform live this is probably the closest I will come, you can hear his voice as you read the anecdotes which I feel really adds to them.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I love Billy Connolly, always have, always will and what a class act Billy really is. This is the best of the very best of the big man's, tall tales and wee stories as he told them on stage. Great reading, great man, great heart

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: If you are a big of Billy, you probably have already heard of the jokes in this book on video or live. But still, it is a great experience to see all the famous jokes all line up together. If you are a fan of Billy, read this book, you will have a great laugh. (As always)

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: 🙌Such a class act. Chuckling all the way through. Some proper classic tales and jokes in this book. Big Connolly fan? Then this is a must have 😂😊.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: A collection of some of his best stories. Not as good as seeing the man perform them but the next best thing. If you love Billy, you'll love this book.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Great to read through some of the classic Connolly stories, very funny

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Absolutely brilliant. I had tears in my eyes and down my cheeks from laughter. Just a great book all round. So glad I picked it up.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I think I’ve read and seen everything Billy Connelly’s ever done, so I’m well aware that he regularly pebbledashes his audience with copious amounts of colourful language. So I was surprised to find myself disturbed by his liberal use of the F word right from the start of his book. In fact on the first page he actually says if you don’t like the F word you can F off right now. Of course this might be because my ten year old granddaughter bought the book for me at Christmas and wants to borrow it, so maybe I was just a prudish grandad being over protective. Anyway, once I got over that hurdle I drove Jennifer mad with sudden outbursts of raucous laughter that got me confined to the conservatory, and I realised I wasn’t actually reading the book - I was hearing Connolly saying it loud and clear in my head as he strutted up and down the stage. Of course the stories are the same ones he’s told many times before, but as some comic used to say, it’s the way he tells them. Having been brought up on the west coast of Ireland in a small terrace house with outside toilet, three brothers and four sisters, I can relate to Connolly’s stories of his childhood in Glasgow. The story of the kid in bed shouting down that Eamon has his foot stuck in the sleeve of the overcoat, and the mortified mother shouting back in front of the visiting priest that it isn’t an overcoat, it’s an eiderdown had done the rounds in our town long before Connolly made us howl with laughter at it. I was even slapped around the head one evening by an inebriated neighbour who thought I was one of his and I should be at home in bed. Great days. The fact is, if you like Connelly you will love this book. But brace yourself – it’s a bumpy ride.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Largely read this during a period of covid-related self-isolation, when the short "chapters" was all I could concentrate on and the humour was a necessary tonic. Indeed some of the stories were laugh out loud funny... causing physical pain to my ribs which were already sore from coughing... Others were probably as funny, but I had either heard them before on old recordings of his gigs (on LPs - yes I am that old) and his TV appearances, or read them in his earlier "Unauthorised Biography". His material was never politically correct, even in the days before such a thing was unheard of... he always navigated the line of what was "acceptable/shocking" frequently crossing it... But there was never any overt sense of malice in his earlier material... even the cack-handed "Last Supper/Crucifixion" story that doesn't come across well on paper, without his distinctive delivery. He was never a "political" comedian... he usually found humour in the ridiculous, and especially the ridiculous that we accept as normal. However, some of his later material, perhaps in the light of the PC/woke climate and the reaction against that by some, comes across as lazily reactionary. He sees the PC/woke agenda as "beige" but instead of taking on substantial examples of this he focusses on reversing beepers on bin-lorries and ambulance being printed back to front on the front of said vehicles. Sadly this merely comes across as him as a relic of a former age raging at a world he doesn't feel part of any more... which is frustrating given that I too am a relic of that former age in which he was a giant. Indeed THE Big Yin.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Moaning about Billy Connolly will win you no friends apart from those of the Mary Whitehouse, Christian Fundamentalist persuasion who probably think he should be hung, drawn and quartered for having the audacity to swear and make fun of the whole religion and sex shebangs. My granny first cast some doubt in my fledgling mind many years ago when I told her I thought Billy was hilarious. "Son," she said, " Ah went tae see him at the Toon Hall. He wiz funny fur a while but Ah goat fed up wi' some o' the language. Ah tellt him tae. Ah said tae him, Billy, ye' kin be funny withoot aw the swearing. So, he stopped whit he wiz dae'in and said tae mi: Whit did you come fur if yi don't like ma swearin'? Ah said, that's no the point. Try no tae swear sae much: it's awe F this and F that wi' ye. Och c'mon on , he said, ye knew whit Ah wiz like before ye' came the night. Billy, Ah said, ye' should stick tae the banjo - sometimes yer patter's rotten".And indeed, sometimes his patter is rotten: several of these stories fall very flat and probably come from his mid-Transatlantic-trying-to-please-Americans years. Personally I like Billy when he swears - it's earthier and more real. The softer stuff about grey pubic hairs and prostates just doesn't do it for me. Much better are the jobbie wheechers and Jesus sliding on dog shit - now that is REAL Glasgow humour.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: For those familiar with Billy Connolly and his way of telling his stories, complete with arm waving and wandering about on stage, this book revisits a great many of those stories. As he reveals in his introduction, sometimes he doesn't know exactly what he will talk about during his stand up sessions, but has perhaps a list of what might occur. The stories frequently ramble with many asides and digressions, as well as sound effects that the readers have to put in for themselves, but they are a true reflection of his stage performances, and for those who have seen those performances, the imagination will kick in and you can envisage him gesticulating and generally enjoying himself with his audience. Many of the stories involve rants that become increasingly amusing, and every story ends with some sort of punch line, but, as Billy himself says, he dose not actually tell jokes, he makes his stories amusing.For those not familiar with Billy Connolly, a word of warning. Billy believes that Keith Tynan did the English language, and television, a great service by being the first person to ever use the F word on television. According to Billy this was a liberating event, so much so, that he enjoys using that word quite liberally in both his stage appearances and this book. If you are easily offended, then this book is not for you. If you believe yourself to be broadminded, then you may well enjoy the ramblings of a truly amusing, and well informed, Glaswegian.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I have never really been a big 'fan' of the Big Yin, although i do like him and do watch his concert movies whenever i happen to see them. I think he is indeed one of the great humourous story-tellers of the past fifty years and have huge respect for his abilities as an entertainer.This book is maybe not the best though, it does seem to be a word for word retelling of some of his stand-u stuff, much of it available on the concert movie 'high horse'. I am pretty sure that the book is a very slightly edited transcription of those routines as I doubt that these are 'scripts' that BC stuck to in his stand-up performances. To be honest, the material doesn't come across as well in book format as they do live, BC's huge personality (even in the afore-mentioned concert video where he was clearly limited in movement) is such a par of the stories - the delivery, the way he tells them - don't always come across when translated to the page.Of course there is some funny stuff here, how could there not be? And for many readers they will indeed laugh out loud. sadly there is some rather tired old stuff too - complaints about people using cellphones for example. The book has been marketed as the best of BC, but really the best is the live performances - stick to those, enjoy and laugh along.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: In December 2018 after years of dominating stages around the world for decades Billy Connolly announced that he was retiring from that part of his repertoire. The onset of Parkinson's disease which he was diagnosed with in 2013 had done what hecklers hadn't been able to.His career began in the 1960's and evolved into a unique presentation of monologues that often changed on the way through and never were the same from night to night. It made him a star, in spite of his fondness for intemperate language.What Tall Tales and Wee Stories sets out to do is to bring some of those very funny monologues to life on the page. If you can longer catch Billy performing then bringing the best of his very funny stories to you is definitely the next best thing.For a man who never wrote scripts Billy Connolly never seemed to be anything but spontaneous and highly entertaining. If you missed out on seeing one of the best comedians grabbing his audiences night after night, then this book is for you. Equally if you've had the pleasure of catching him live you might recognise some of these wee tales.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: The first part of this book had me laughing until I cried! Billy was his usual self and the Party story .... don't get me started or I won't stop laughing again. So far so good . Then a few stories some of which I'd heard quite a few years before and then the book went down hill. The F word was used in practical every sentence . Yes I know he warned us in the beginning of the book but this just became a bore . The last few stories just sound like an old man having a rant at our expense and it was off putting and rather dirty old man stuff .it seems unless you are some kind of weirdo , pervert or alcoholic Billy looks down on the rest of us and would probably tell you to F off if he saw you. Beige I understand that one , we have all met a BEEEIGEE person who has bored the socks off us , but he implies that 99% of us are rather below his standard . That is not acceptable. The last stories about his illness might have made me think more empathetically but the previous rants swearing and rather weird schoolboy dirty stories left me to a degree rather uninterested. Perhaps the last bit of the book was down to his illness as it was certainly different to the first half .

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: It's not possible to say anything bad about Billy Connolly. He's a national treasure.This book recounts many of the tales he has used in his stage shows over the years. So as a fan from his first double album 'Solo Concert' recorded in 1974, many of the stories were familiar to me. And for that reason only, did I not give this book the full 5 star rating.But there are still some priceless tales in here that will make you laugh out loud - especially if as Billy suggests at the start, you read the book in his accent. (Actually - try NOT to ... it's impossible!) :-DThe short tale of the Wildebeast is a case in point. Hilarious!Even though much of this is not new material, it is still an great read, and in fact, I love the idea of having the source of so much mirth being committed to written form.The words and humour will never leave.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Billy released this book upon his retirement from stand-up comedy at the end of 2018. It’s a compilation of his best stories from his long career on stage, and it does what it says on the tin. It’s a very comforting read for long-time fans, although we all know his comedy is best in videos where he’s performed live. I very much enjoyed reading some old favourite stories that I’d nearly forgotten about, like when he got stuck doing yoga or got lost after his rental car’s GPS “got mad at him” for missing his turn and stopped working. Favourites from my childhood.He seems to acknowledge at the end of the book that he’s in his final years now as his health declines, which made for a bit of a heavy ending, but also a positive one. He’s at peace with his Parkinson’s and is happy with how he has lived his life, and he wants everyone to just keep laughing. What a special guy.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Not for me,I bought this book because I saw some of his performance on video and wanted to get to know more of a native Scottish view on Scotland before visiting, you know trying to relate a little.. I smiled through the first pages and then tried really hard to read past the first 1/3, but as a non-native English and not familiar with the Scottish language, I was quickly disconnected not knowing the references and not understanding all the expression. Plus, some stories were so unreal that I had a hard time believing it really happened..Hence, it is difficult for me to give a rating as I would say that this book was just not for me in the first place and I will keep on laughing at his video performance when I cross some but try to relate with Scotland vision of another author writing more in a Queen's English language type.. ;) Sorry Billy

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I must start by saying that I have been a fan of Billy since I was a teenager and I have seen him perform live. I have also enjoyed him as an actor and presentor, and so I looked forward to reading this book even though I knew what to expect.Alas, I have been sadly disappointed as I believe that this is just a transcript of his performance stories and if you hoped to find out more about the man himself this is not the book for you. He speaks from the pages, but there is little to help create the mental images of the stories he tells and there appears nothing new.It is probably as much my own fault as I probably expected too much, but in reality I have heard it all before. Health and time is catching up with Billy and he will no longer perform, and so for those new to him this is a good substitute. I did find his drawings interesting and I wish him well.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I’m not normally a fan of northern comedians, especially ones which use potty humour and tends to swear a lot. But this autobiography is quite interesting. Connolly does tend to digress a bit (of which we are forewarned) and often it takes a while to get back to the original subject. But what does come out of these musings is a long zest of a life well lived and some interesting and colourful characters found in the most common of places. And he’s never afraid to talk about his hometown roots, or anything really, as there’s rather a lot of talk about poo. But hey, it’s all natural. Everyone loves it when people lose their rag and ends up being a bit naughty, and you gain a sense that a lot of people don’t really grow up at all. It’s a good read to pass the time and you get a sense of Connolly’s lifestyle and act; but there few moments that make you want to smirk or laugh out loud. It’s probably a good idea that I didn’t go and see his act really.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: 2 and half starsEver since being a lad, I’ve always found Billy to be a fascinating, down-to-Earth, humorous storyteller.Sadly, this doesn’t translate well into words in this collection. I did laugh! But mainly because I could recall Billy’s tone and mannerisms when he’s delivered some of these stories on stage. As another reviewer has said, what you have here is a transcript of oral delivery—but it doesn’t flow well enough for a reading experience, which is a real shame. Sometimes, it just feels disjoined, the “sound effects” don’t work most of the time, the expletives don’t carry any weight (and often feel like unnecessary distractions), and the tangents don’t elevate the main stories as well as they could.Hopefully, one day, someone will edit this collection and rearrange these wee stories so that they can deliver the impact that they have had when performed.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: This didn't do much for me. I thought it would be a bit more autobiographical but it's more like a transcript of how he might tell a story at a show, and as I understand it many of the stories in this collection are actually ones he's used as material over the years. The end result frequently isn't funny at all and totally falls flat. If anything this probably highlights what a natural performer he is - a gifted story teller that uses charisma, timing and nuance that could make reading the phonebook funny. As it is it's a collection of observations and pub jokes without much punch.I'd also say a solid 5% of this is onomatopoeic noises. If there wasn't a section about his hatred for computers and technology I'd have guessed he wrote this by using Voice To Text software and just allowing it to interpret his various impressions of fart noises like "PFFFFFFFTTTTTOOOOoooRP".

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Tall Tales and Wee Stories and Billy Connolly transcribing many of his best stand-up jokes/tales. As a big BC fan, this was familiar ground for me and great fun. During the books into BC that you’d read the book in his accent and I found it impossible not to do so. I also frequently ‘watched along’ as I picture his actual stand up so still got is great ‘physical’ story telling and facial expressions. I did wonder if this was hand to someone who had never seen any of his stand up if they would get just how funny many of the jokes are? I.e. half the time it was how Billy told the joke or stomped round the stage etc that added to the humour. Would what for me is a belly laugh be a wry smile for the uninitiated? Either way, I loved it.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Puny in Farts? Funny in parts?I have always loved Billy C, after seeing him live in 1980. His natural talent coupled with his ability to observe humour in everything is unique and wonderful. But so much of Billy’s humour is visual and that doesn’t translate easily into writing. That said, I did enjoy reading this book even though I had heard most of the stories before and some certainly don’t improve in re-telling them on paper. If Billy still feels the need to try to make his audience laugh in order to prove something to himself (or pay the tax man) then that’s sad. He certainly doesn’t need to prove anything to his audience...He is and always will be one of the funniest men to have lived. Thank you for the tall tales and wee stories.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: This is a dip in and out book. I'm glad it's not one I chose for a holiday or long flight. There are stories in the book which made me shake with laughter and others that I didn't bother finishing.The thing is, when you've seen him live on stage and you are one of hundreds of others on a night out he has the knack of telling the story that links you to life and those around you. Common understanding and you laugh at yourselves and with him. If the audience doesn't respond to his takes he knows to change or move it in a different direction.Probably, in truth, the reason I was disappointed was because of my own expectations and not because of the writing. The key thing is that I still regard him as a good laugh! Thanks Billy.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Much as I have loved Billy's career since first seeing him and Gerry in the Glasgow Folk centre in 1968 I can only say thatthis book was mostly a rehash of material from albums, television appearances and they were good but have been round the block many times. The newer things were quite peurile. Billy seems to have a desire to tell everyone else that they are wrong and he wants to prove he is a big boy and the amount of his swearing was diabolical. It seemed like somebody who may have attended school but forgot to the English classes when he can't use the language on a higher plane.Disappointed me and the most joy I got from the book was knowing that I found the for £1 at a charity shop instead of having to pay the cover price of £20 to be so disappointed

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Bill Connolly is, above all else, a master storyteller with incredibly funny bones, and one of my comedy heroes. I’ve listened to his records (thanks Dad), and watched his stand up on television. My only regret is the fact I’ve never seen him live. Sadly, that won’t be changing. Tall Tales and Wee Stories is a marvellous collection of some of his best sketches ever, peppered with his unique style of art. You cannot read this book in any other accent than his. Impossible. On the odd occasion I’ve put the book down (not often, I can tell you), I’ve got straight back into it. It’s put a smile on my face and raised more than a few hearty, belly laughs. I highly recommend it to anyone in need of a good chuckle.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: 2 1/2 * The thing about Billy Connolly is it was all about his performance; his accent, the way he used his voice, his swearing, the way he flicked his hair, the way he strode around the stage. Reading this I’m almost entirely convinced that it’s transcribed from comedy routines I’ve seen on TV (surely the park the bike story was taken from his interview on Parky?) or recordings of his gigs. I don’t think for a minute that Billy Connolly sat down and wrote this out word for word at some point, or even dictated it. A lot of the material seems quite dated now, but amusing enough if you can hear his voice or remember seeing him tell the story. But not good enough to continue past 66% of the book.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: A laugh out loud rendition of Billy Connollys stand-up routine. The book flows so well and his stories appear so spontaneous. His comedy is so fresh and he obviously thrives in front of a live audience.He covers all aspects of life from his job as a welder in the shipyards of Glasgow to multiple orgasms. Connolly is a unique comedian and it is so sad that he has been diagnosed with Parkinsons disease, (which is a subject he covers in the book, with humour) but it does not get him down, as he says in his book "thank you for laughing with me. And please keep it up". Definitely a book worth reading.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Lots of this is very funny but as someone who has been lucky enough to see the great man on stage, it's not as wonderful as experiencing these stories with all of the attitude, fury and warmth that he musters.There are plenty of gems here - the Last Supper as it happened in Glasgow, the Jobbie Weecha, Hotel Room in Perth and more.Along the way there are little sneaks of Connolly's philosophy of life - how to be on constant guard against beigeness, the joy of swearing.It is sad, but inevitable that Billy will not perform live again but this book, at least, gives is a slice of the magic whenever we reach for the bookcase.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I'd give this so many more stars than 5 if I could!! Honestly was absolutely brilliant and just what I needed. It reads like watching his standup, tall tales and wee stories is exactly what it is and its amazing!!One thing I enjoyed was the fact that there was no plot to follow, no characters to remember and nothing to figure out. It was relaxed reading at its finest. No matter where you stopped you picked up and carried on without having to remember what previously happened. I laughed so much at this book! I've honestly never read anything that has made me laugh til tears ran down my face like this did. This will remain a firm favourite read of this year!!

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: I’ve loved Billy Connolly since before I should really have been listening to Billy Connolly. I remember asking my Gran what his VHS ‘Erect for 30 Years’ meant and not quite understanding why she was so coyish about it. This book is essentially a collection of all the most famous stories he’s told in his many years of stand up comedy. I wasn’t really expecting anything other than that but it still ended up falling a little bit flat. Some of the stories are still great to read and will produce a few belly-laughs but this feels like something for a time machine in case all recordings of the Big Yin have perished over time. Don’t get me wrong, its’ a good read - and a quick one - but it’s just not the same as hearing and seeing Billy tell it. I think it’s worth remembering the words of another comic - Harry Carson - when he said “It’s how I tell ‘em” when you pick this up. My advice - go to YouTube and watch the man in person!

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Billy Connolly is funny and at times hilarious but probably this book full of stand up stories is best on the stage with an audience breaking its sides. Some of the stories lose something when put on paper and a number I have witnessed on the TV but any book that makes you laugh out loud every two or three pages is still worth reading. The language and the subjects can be a bit course but to enjoy the humor you have to take the rough with the smooth. Mutch of this book was taken in sessions before dropping off at night but none of the stories gave me sleepless nights - I'm not sure if that's praise or not for someone who's no bad storyteller!

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Might not work so well if you haven't seen TBCOAT (The Best Comedian Of All Time) preforming some of the routines (eg incontinence Pants, drinking Zombies) because of the sheer physicality of some of the humour. If, however, you have seen live or TV performances, your imagination will take you straight there. Although, as the man says, he's not been a great teller of jokes, my eternal thanks to Billy and his editors for including what is beyond disputation the best punchline gag in the known Universe EVER - Ivan the Terrible.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: A laugh out loud bookThis book was worth the five stars just for the anecdotes. But added to that the fact that Billy included a section on his Parkinson's disease and being Bill had to make a joke of it. I would recommend this book for everyone who is feeling down, and especially with what the world is going through at the moment. You will smile all day even if you just read story by story. My problem was I couldn't put it down and read it in 3 days...... But I will re-read it just to make me smile.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: A depressingly poor book. One of my comedy heroes but his on stage genius doesn’t translate to the page other than a handful of stories and asides. This is a collection of classic skits reproduced verbatim, some (nowhere near enough) amusing or occasionally funny stories and far too many musings that leave you grimacing and wondering what the hell that was and how you can reclaim the time you’ve just wasted. After the first few pages I committed to finishing the book and I stuck to that. We all make mistakes. Do yourself a favour and stick vintage Billy on the telly instead.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: What's not to like about this national treasure? This book is a collection of tales, some you will know from his various tv shows, some from his Audience With Billy Connolly but some are new snippets out in there to have you stifling your chuckles whilst Kay in bed next to your sleeping other half. Personally I love Billy and always have, he sees the funny side of mundane every day occurrences and that to me is priceless. Give yourself a chuckle under the eiderdown or maybe it's an overcoat and your leg's down the sleeve!

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Billy Connolly is my hero. He's his unapologetic self in this wonderful collection of stories from his life as a stand-up comedian, and if you don't find much to tickle your funny bone in this book, then there's something wrong with you! One of the things I love about Billy is that he's still just an ordinary approachable guy - or at least that's the way he comes across. However, 'ordinary' is really the last thing he is - he has such a unique and frankly honest view of things without being cruel. I'd read anything by him.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: A brilliant performer and a British National Treasure. But this didn’t really work for me which surprised me a lot. Firstly you must read it while “hearing” Billy’s voice and accent but it still falls slightly flat. When you see his stories/jokes/tales written down you miss the delivery and the way he riffs between stories or goes off at a tangent, because here they lack the delivery and the performance, they fall surprisingly flat.He is a lovely, warm and witty guy, but this didn’t work for me at all.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: This was brilliant. I laughed out loud many times, I "read" it in his voice and could often picture what he'd be doing while telling the stories. I read this in the space of a couple of days but it could just as easily work if you're someone who just liked to be able to pick up a book read for ten minutes or so and then put it down again. I'm going to see if they have this on Audible and I'd he's reading it, in which case this would be a must have. I think this is a book you could return to often.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Not really an autobiography, just a collection of stories some of which might even be true, about Billy Connolly's life which he had in the past used as stage material in some cases. So a collection of short stories/wee tales about events in his life, or his opinions on topics. Some were hillarious and it was very easy to read them with his voice in your head which makes them even funnier. I could only read one or two in a session sometimes as I was too busy laughing at one. An enjoyable collection of amusing tales.

book_title: Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy Connolly
text: Have you ever laughed out loud at something you’re reading? And I don’t mean a snigger, or a giggle, or even a chuckle. I mean an explosive, snort of a laugh. A joyous, spontaneous release. The kind of laugh that makes everyone else around you smile, even though they have no idea what the joke is. Well, this gem from the master raconteur Billy Connolly will have you cackling like a hyena on almost every page. Nobody, and I mean nobody, tells stories like Billy Connolly.
